conversations.value: It's a shilling for the dock space, and you're going to have to give me your name.
It's remarkable how often those two traits coincide.
Welcome to Port Royal, Mr. Smith.
What do you say to three shillings, and we forget the name?
Some sort of to-do up at the fort, eh? You two weren't invited?
Sorry, I didn't know.
Ship.
This must be some important boat.
Captain Norrington's made it his flagship. He'll use it to hunt down the last dregs of piracy on the Spanish Lake.
Ship.
Oh, the Dauntless is the power in these waters, true enough -- but there's no ship that can match the Interceptor for speed.
That's a fine goal, I'm sure ... But it seems to me a ship like that -- (indicates the Dauntless) -- makes this one here just a wee superfluous.
There's no real ship as can match the Interceptor.
That so? I've heard of one, supposed to be fast, nigh uncatchable ... the Black Pearl?
What's your name?
I'm sorry. It's just such a pretty boat. Ship.
What's your business in Port Royal, 'Mr. Smith' ?
Smith.
I said, no lies.
None? Very well. You've rumbled me. I confess: I intend to commandeer one of these ships, pick up a crew in Tortuga, and go out on the account, do a little honest pirating.
May I have a moment?
Unless, of course, he knew you wouldn't believe the truth if he told it to you.
I can't swim.
Aren't you going to save her?
Fine.
(rolls his eyes) Sailors.
I never would have thought of that.
Move.
Where did you get this?
Clearly, you've never been to Singapore.
I don't see your ship -- Captain.
Captain Jack Sparrow. If you please.
Carefully, lieutenant.
Ah, but you have heard of me.
(smiles) Indeed.
But it seems to be enough to condemn him.
(backing away, toward land) Commodore Norrington ... my pistol and belt, please.
Finally.
Now, if you'll be very kind?
Miss Swann, if you'll be so kind?
Gentleman. .. m' lady. .. you will always remember this as the day you almost caught Captain Jack Sparrow.
I saved your life; now you've saved mine. We're square.
I've made a point of avoiding familiarity with pirates.
You look familiar ... Have I ever threatened you before?
Do you think this is wise, boy? Crossing blades with a pirate?
Ah. Then it would be a shame to put a black mark on your record. So if you'll excuse me ...
You know what you're doing, I'll give you that ... Excellent form ... But how's your footwork? If I step here -
Only a little.
No. I practice three hours a day so that when I meet a pirate ... I can kill him.
You need to find yourself a girl. (Will sets his jaw) Or maybe the reason you practice three hours a day is you've found one -- but can't get her?
Move away.
(smiles; what do you expect?) Pirate.
No. I can not just step aside and let you escape.
Move!
Excellent work, Mister Brown. You've aided in the capture of a dangerous fugitive.
You're lucky, boy -- this shot's not meant for you.
Excuse us if we ain't resigned ourselves to the gallows just yet.
You can keep doing that forever, that dog's never going to move.
It's the Black Pearl.
I know those guns!
Governor! Barricade yourself in my office! (Swann hesitates) That's an order!
There are a lot of stories about the Black Pearl.
What's the matter, boy?
It's all right, doggie ... come here,
You are cursed.
Worry about your own fortunes. The lowest circle of hell is reserved for betrayers ... and mutineers.
Where does it make berth?
Somewhat.
The ship's real enough. So its anchorage must be a real place. Where is it?
Surely you've heard the stories? The Black Pearl sails from the dreaded Isla de Mureta... an island that cannot be found -- except by those who already know where it is.
Because you're a pirate.
Why ask me?
Never. (beat) They took Miss Swann.
And you want to turn pirate yourself?
I can get you out of here.
(he was right) So it is that you found a girl. Well, if you're intending to brave all and hasten to her rescue and so win fair lady's heart, you'll have to do it alone. I see no profit in it for me.
(examines the cell) I helped build these cells. Those are hook-and-ring hinges. The proper application of strength, the door'll lift free. Just calls for the right lever and fulcrum. . .
How? The key's run off.
Yes. Will Turner.
Your name is Turner.
Agreed.

Will Turner... (he stands) I'll tell you what, Mr. Turner. I've changed my mind. You spring me from this cell, and on pain of death, I'll you to the Black Pearl. (sticks out his hand) Do we have an accord?
Someone will have heard that. Hurry.
Agreed!
We need to go!
Not without my effects.
(no hesitation) I'd die for her.
My business, Will. As for your business -one question, or there's no use going. (joins Will at the door) This girl -- what does she mean to you? How far are you willing to go to save her?
I knew the Harbormaster wouldn't report her. Honest men are slaves to their conscience, and there's no predicting 'em. But you can always trust a dishonest man to stay that way...
Good.
Besides, we are about to better our prospects considerably.
No worries there. She's far more likely to rot out from under us.
It's still against the law.
Commandeer. We're going to commandeer a ship. Nautical term.
This is either crazy, or brilliant.
So's breaking a man out of jail. Face it, Will: you may say you'll never be a pirate, but you're off to a rip-roaring start. (smiling) My advice -- smile and enjoy it.
(a beat) Aye! Avast!
Remarkable how often those two traits coincide. Everybody stay calm. We're taking over the ship!
You understand this ship cannot be crewed by only two men. You'll never make it out of the bay.
Dead serious.
Sir, I'll not see any of my men killed or wounded in this foolish enterprise.
We'll see about that.
(a curt nod) Agreed. You have the momentary advantage, sir. But I will see you smile from the yard arm sir.
Fine by me. We brought you a nice little boat, so you can all get back to shore, safe and sound.
I can't believe he's doing this.
As likely as not. (calling) Will, short up the anchor, we've got ourselves a ship! A little help?
Commodore --
Lookee there, mate! We're underway!
Of course, sir. Like a fish. I grew up summers living in Dover, with my uncle -
Can you swim? (the man struggles) Can. You. Swim?
Sailors! Back to the Interceptor!
Good.
Raise the sails.
Thank you, Commodore, for getting our ship ready to make way! We'd've had a hard time of it by ourselves!
I worked passage   from England as a cabin boy. (an attempt  at guile) After my mother  passed, I came out here ... looking  for my father.
For a man whose made an industry of avoiding boats, you're a quick study.
My father. William Turner?
Is that so?
'Bootstrap?'
I knew him. Probably one of the few who knew him as William Turner. Most everyone just called him Bill, or 'Bootstrap' Bill.
(angry) That's not true.
Good man. Good pirate. And clever -"- I never met anyone with as clever a mind and hands as him. When you were puzzling out that cell door, it was like seeing his twin.
It's not true that my father was a pirate.
I swear, you look just like him.
He was a merchant marine! He was a respectable man who obeyed the law, and followed the rules--
Figured you wouldn't want to hear it.
My father did not think of my mother -his family -- as a burden.

(laughs) You think your father is the only man who ever lived the Glasgow life, telling folk one thing, and then going off to do another? There's quite a few who come here, hoping to amass enough swag to ease the burdens of respectable
My father -- was not -- a pirate!
Sure -- because he could always go pirating.
You didn't beat me. You ignored the rules of engagement. In a fair fight, I'd kill you.
Put it away, Will. It's not worth getting beat again.
As long as you're just hanging there, pay attention. Must, Should, do, don't, shall, shall not -- those are just suggestions. There are only two absolute rules. (ticks them off on his fingers)
Then that's not much incentive for me to fight fair, is it?
Just do it quickly.
Oh -- did I forget to mention that?
You stole my boat.
(rubbing his jaw) Don't worry. I've already got my Quartermaster -- there!
Borrowed. Borrowed your boat. (off her look) Without permission.
AnaMaria! Have you seen Gibbs? I need to put together -
That boat is my livelihood!
Safe! At Port Royal. With the Royal Navy.
(a threat) I will.
You'll get it back. Or one better.
Aye, that'll about do it.
Well, fortunately, I know how to counter it. The man who did the waking buys the man who was sleeping a drink, and the man who was sleeping it drinks it while listening to a proposition.
Make it_ast, then. Now, what's the nature of this venture of yours?
Just the one.
Oh, there's a hard tale, Jack. Most of the decent pirates in town won't sail with you -- seem to think you're a jinx.
First -- have you found me a crew?
I'm going after the Black Pearl.
Now where, I wonder, would they have gotten that idea?
Jack, it's a fool's errand: You've heard the tales they tell about the Pearl.
Ilm going after the Black Pearl. I know where its going to be, and I'm going to take it.
(shakes his head) A fool's errand.
Aye, and that's why I know where it's going to be, and that's why I know what Barbossa is up to. All I need is a crew.
And you've got that, have you?
Not if the fool has something Barbossa wants. Something he needs.
Well, lookee there. I'll allow you may be onto something, Jack. (considers, nods) There's bound to be sailors on this rock crazy as you. I'll find some men.
Back there, guarding the door is the son of old Bootstrap Bill Turner.
Feast your eyes, Cap'n. All of 'em good sea-faring men, faithful hands before the mast, every one worth his salt --
That he is.
Wind in your SAILS! Wind in your SAILS!
Mr. Cotton. Do you have the courage and fortitude to follow orders and stay true, in the face danger, and almost certain death?
Shut up, before you lose them all!
That goes for the rest of you! Danger and near certain death. (turns away) For we are to sail for the Isla de Muerta, to rescue the daughter of Governor Swann. An equal share of the reward shall be -
That fool will have us lose the canvas, and the masts besides!
These are the only ones worth having. (glances at the sky) And we're going to need them-
(shouts) What's in your head to put you in such a fine mood?
She can hold a bit longer.
Isla de Muerta! Isla de Muerta, off the port bow!
(shouts) We're catching up!
Six points port!
Bear three points starboard.
My body's still there, rotting away, and I am but a ghost!
(loud) I didn't!
Wait -- what about the pistol?
Ah, that's a dark and unpleasant tale, best left untold.
But I survived. And I still have that single shot. It's meant for one man. My mutinous first mate -

The pistol. When a pirate is marooned, Will, he's given a pistol with a single shot. No good for hunting, or surviving, really. But after three weeks of starvation and thirst -- the option of that pistol begins to look good.
The curse drove you to gather this?
They'll be anchored on the lee side. Haul your wind, and keep to the weather of the island -
On what?
Depends.
-- well, too late.
On whether the stories are    all true. If they are, that's    a waterfall that spills over    at high tide, with a short drop to    an underground lagoon. If not    -
Here we stand before the cursed treasure of Cortez himself. Won by blood, it demands blood in return.
Chalk one up for the stories.
You're in league with Barbossa!
Me!
You?!
No, I'm -- rescuing you.
I'm glad we got here in time.
This way!
Come on!
The trick isn't getting here, it's getting away.
No.
No. This won't work. (a quick decision) I'll stay behind, and fight them. You go on.
Go to the opposite end of the island, and signal the ship. I'll keep 'em busy.
I'll lead them away.
I invoke the right of parlay, according to the Code of the Brethren, set down by the pirates Morgan and Bartholomew...
I'm sure. When you've led the kind of life I have, there are debts that must be paid. Maybe I can balance the scales a little.
I know who's blood you need, to end the curse.
The woman's blood didn't work, did it?
Now?
No you won't.
The Pearl? (laughs) Oh, that's fine. And just how do you expect this to work?
Simple. I have something you want more than anything. The way to free you from the curse of the treasure. You have something I want -- more than anything.
That's your offer? You, sailing away nice and pretty with the Black Pearl, and all I have is a name?
You give me the Pearl. Then I tell you who you need.
I'm supposed to ... trust you?
That's right.
You see, I've got this honest streak in me -- in its own way, a sort of curse. Oh, and there's the fact that you have no choice.
I'm a man of my word.
Blast you! I'll throw you in prison.
You left me on a desert island -- what worse can you do?
You're setting me up for a double cross, you with the ship, and me with nothing more than your word!
Wait as long as you like.
Track you down and -
Let's say I tell you the wrong person. What would you do?
Jack, I don't trust you, and that's a fact. Never trust a smiling man, you can lay to that.
And if I tell you the truth, you become mortal, and you won't come near me because you know I'd kill you.
You're playing this as close to the edge as any man, I'll give you that. (decides, smiles)
See, that's where we're different. I trust you ... to do what it takes to get what you want.
That fool woman took it. You be careful around her, Jack -- she's pretty enough, she'll steal your heart -- but pure evil inside.
What -- you don't have the medallion?
Bosun! Set up Mr. Sparrow's quarters, nice and fine ... in the brig. (to Jack, a smile) Meaning no disrespect, of course.
I'll watch my back.
Strike your colors, you bloody cockroaches!
Don't hit my ship! I mean, kill the lying scoundrel - (to Twigg) I'm a little conflicted, here.

My name is Will Turner, the son of Bootstrap Bill Turner. His blood runs in my veins. (raises the gun to his head) You need my blood. And on my word I will pull this trigger, and sink all the way down to Davy Jones' Locker!
Will -- don't do anything stupid! Don't say anything stupid -
Now, Jack. That reef is less than a league distant. It's a square deal all around, and you can't hope for better.
It's pure evil to make a Captain walk the plank of his own ship, twice in one lifetime. No good can come of it.
You'd best take a swim, Jack.
Someone needs to cut these bonds, then.
That's proper, sir, according to the code.
The last time you did this, you left me a pistol, with one shot.
Tell you what. I'll   give you one pistol, and let you   be the gentleman, an' shoot the lady,   and starve to death yourself! (grins) That is, presuming   you're not both drownded.
A gentleman might give us two pistols, seeing as there are two of us, this time.
That's fair.
You can go to your grave not knowing.
Has it changed since the last time you were here?
That's the second time I've had to watch that man sail away with my ship.
I hope you have no intention of using that.
The trees are taller.
Captain Sparrow! We have to get off this island -- immediately!
Not yet. Ask me again in a few weeks.
What is that? Is there a boat under there?
Don't be thinking I'm not already working on it.
But ... you did it before! Last time -
It won't. It won't, and so we won't.
But from the looks of this, they've long been'out of business, and so that won't be happening again. (takes another swig) We probably have your friend Norrington to thank for that.
Last time, I was here a grand total of three days. Last time, the rumrunners who used this island as a cache came by, and I bartered passage off.

You should look at our contretemps this way: we've got shade trees, thank the Lord. We've got some food on the trees, thank the Lord again. And we've got rum, praise the Lord. We can stay alive a month, maybe more. Keep a weather eye open for passing ships, and our chances are fair.
Welcome to the Caribbean, love.
Don't be thinking I'm happy about this, Elizabeth. But I see no use in wailing and gnashing my teeth over that which I can do nothing about.
You're right. (hoists the bottle) Here's luck to you, Will Turner.
And you will call me Miss Swann.
Try it. It goes down rough, but it goes down - - and the second swig goes down easier.
Nothing ... it's nothing. Just ... I'm reminded of a song I learned as a child. A song about pirates.
What? What was that? (Elizabeth smiles) Something funny, Miss Swann? share. Please,
Oh, no ... it's silly.   Back in England we didn't know   a thing about pirates, really.   They seemed so romantic and daring   -
I know a lot of songs about pirates, but none I'd teach a child. Let's hear it.
Well, perhaps ... with a bit more to drink, I might ...
Now I must hear this song. An authentic pirate song. Have at it.
Well?
More to drink!
When I get the   Black Pearl back, I'm going to teach   it to the whole crew, and we'll sing   it all the time!
I LOVE this song! (sings) Yo ho, yo ho, a pirate's life for me! We're beggars and blighters,
Jack, it must be so terrible for you, to be trapped here on this island, all over again.

Not just the Spanish Main. The whole ocean. .. the whole world. Wherever we want to go, we go. That's what a ship is, you know. Not just a keel and a hull and a deck and sails. That's what a ship need_ ... but what a ship is -- what the Black Pearl really-is ... is freedom.
(coy)
Ah, well... the company is better than last time. And the scenery has definitely improved.
To freedom.
We've got a few bottles left ... and we've yet to tap the kegs.
Yes, the rum is gone.
To the Black Pearl. What are you doing? You've burned our food, the shade -- the rum!
One, because it is a vile drink that turns even the most respectable men into scoundrels. Two -
Why?
Exactly.
You -- you burned up the island, for a one-time chance at being spotted?
Elizabeth, I'm" relieved you're safe. (re: Jack) Clap him in irons. And behind his back this time.
They'll be no living with her after this.
We are bound for Port Royal, not Isla de Muerta.
(she's right) We had time to get to know each other.
By remembering that I serve others, not only myself.
Norrington, think about it ... the Black Pearl, its captain and crew... the last pirate threat in the Caribbean. How can you pass that up?
Elizabeth, I hereby withdraw my proposal.
Congratulations, sir.
He might delay the rescue ... and that would be too late.
Nor did you, I noticed.
These men will be facing an enemy that seemingly cannot be killed.
Exactly.
What's your plan?
I have a plan. If it succeeds, then any battle will be decidedly brief ... and one-sided.
You would do that?
Funny, I was thinking   along those lines. How about you let me   go in alone, and while you're setting   up an ambush, I'll trick the pirates out   to you.
(looks at him) Nothing I wouldn't be please to be rid of.
They left me stranded. Twice. What have you got to lose?
I'll be at the wheel myself.
(smiles) I knew you'd listen to reason! That chart I drew up'11 get you past the reefs. If you're steersman's good enough, that is.
No reason to fret. It's just a prick of the finger and a few drops of blood.
I'll slip in, talk them into to come out, and you'll be free to blow holy high heaven the whole lot of them.
Jack!
Do you have any idea where you're going?
Are you certain this is the right way?
Don't talk. These caves magnify sound. Just follow me.
Thank you, Jack Sparrow.
It's the right way.
No, I really think I do.
You don't want to be doing that.
Why don't I want to do this?
(shrugs) All right then.
Jack!
Because, right about now, the H.M.S. Dauntless is lying in wait in the harbor.
Do you believe him?
- - and its guns and crew will cut you and your men to pieces the moment you step outside these caves.
What're you suggesting?
You've no hope of surviving Norrington's attack ... that is, if you're mortal.
(drops the coins one-by- one back into the chest) Like after you've killed... Every... Last ... One ... of Norrington's men.
Simple. Don't kill the boy yet. Wait for a more opportune moment.
That so?
The situation has changed.

I sail for you as part of your fleet, I give you fifteen percent of my plunder, and you get to introduce yourself at tea parties and brothels as 'Commodore Barbossa.' (sticks out his hand) Do we have an accord?

Aye. See, after you're done with the Royal Navy, you'll have a bit of a problem: the H.M.S. Dauntless. There you'll be, with two lovely ships on your hands, and what to do? Of course you'll decide you deserve the bigger one, and who's to argue? The Dauntless a first-rate ship-of-line, and with it, you can rule the seas. (beat)
Aye, for us there is.
There's ... another exit?
Use it well.
Oh, please -- do I really seem that clever?
You can't beat me, Jack.
Remarkable how often those two traits coincide.
They're so pretty, I just couldn't resist stealing one. It's a curse, I guess.
Well, isn't that interesting.
Or I could chain you to a cannonball and drop you in the deepest part of the ocean, where you can contemplate your folly forever.
Or you could surrender.
Let's get out of here.

(admits it) The worst. (beat) On the other hand, maybe I'm a man who can't pass up a chance for revenge against the black-hearted bastard who stole my ship and left me to die in the middle of the ocean -- twice! -- and who knows how to get what he wants. Now that's a great pirate.
...and though I do say so with regret, the law is clear. The penalty for piracy is death by hanging.
Tough luck. I was rooting for you.
Aye, aye, sir!
AnaMaria, trim the mainsail!
FADE OUT and CREDITS ROLL
Mr. Gibbs, organize a cleaning detail - you and Cotton. I want every inch of the Pearl spic-and-span and ship-shape!
What ' hey. Hold up, there, you. It's a shilling to tie up your boat at the dock. And I shall need to know your name.
What d'ye say to three shillings' and we forget the name?
This dock is off limits to civilians.

I'm terribly sorry. I didn't know. If I see one, I shall inform you immediately. Apparently there's some sort of high toned and fancy to do up at the fort, eh' How could it be that two upstanding gentlemen such as yourselves did not merit an invitation?
Someone has to make sure this dock stays off limits to civilians.
It's a fine goal to be sure but it seems to me that a' a ship like that makes this one here a bit superfluous, really.
Oh, the Dauntless is the power in these waters, true enough, but there's no ship as can match the Interceptor for speed.
I've heard of one, supposed to be very fast ' nigh un-catchable'the Black Pearl.
You don't have permission to be aboard there, mate.
I'm sorry, it's just - it's such a pretty boat. Ship.
What's your name?
That would be Jack Sparrow.
If he were telling the truth, he wouldn't have told us.
Unless, of course, he knew you wouldn't believe the truth even if he told it to you.
Scene 4: (The daring rescue and escape)
'and then they made me their chief.
The rocks! Sir, it's a miracle she missed them.
Will you be saving her then?
I can't swim.
Pride of the King's Navy you are. Do not lose these.
What was that' Ooh, I got her. She's not breathing!
Move!
Never would've thought of that.
Clearly you've never been to Singapore . Where did you get that?
Keep your guns on him, men. Gillette , fetch some irons. Well, well' Jack Sparrow , isn't it?
Captain Jack Sparrow , if you please, sir.
Well, I don't see your ship'Captain.
I'm in the market as it were.
No additional shots nor powder. A compass that doesn't point north. And I half expected it to be made of wood. You are without doubt the worst pirate I've ever heard of.
But you have heard of me.
One good deed is not enough to redeem a man of a lifetime of wickedness.
Though it seems enough to condemn him.
Indeed.
Finally.
Governor Swann : No, don't shoot!
I knew you'd warm up to me. Commodore Norrington, my effects, please, and my hat. Commodore! Elizabeth . It is Elizabeth isn't it?
It's Miss Swann .
Miss Swann , if you'd be so kind. Come, come, dear. We don't have all day. Now if you'd be very kind. Easy on the goods, darling.
You're despicable.
Sticks and stones, love. I saved your life, you save mine, we're square. Gentlemen, m'lady, you will always remember this as the day that you almost caught Captain Jack Sparrow !
Scene 5: (The duel between Jack and Will )
Whoa!
Right where I left you. Not where I left you. You're the one they're hunting. The pirate.
You seem somewhat familiar. Have I threatened you before?
I make a point of avoiding familiarity with pirates.
Ah, well, then it would be a shame to put a black mark on your record. So, if you'll excuse me' Do you think this wise, boy ' crossing blades with a pirate?
You threatened Miss Swann .

Only a little. You know what you're doing. I'll give you that. Excellent form. But how's your footwork' If I step here; very good. Now I step again. Ta. That is a wonderful trick' except, once again you are between me and my way out. And now you have no weapon. Who makes all these'
I do! And I practice with them' three hours a day!

You need to find yourself a girl, mate! Or perhaps the reason you practice three hours a day is that you already found one and are otherwise incapable of wooing said strumpet. You're not a eunuch, are you'
I practice three hours a day so that when I meet a pirate, I can kill it! You cheated!
Pirate! Move away.
No.
Please move.
No! I cannot just step aside and let you escape.
This shot is not meant for you.
Come here, boy. Want a nice juicy bone' Come here. Come on
You can keep doing that forever, the dog is never going to move.
Cannon fire! Return fire!
I know those guns. It's the Pearl .
The Black Pearl ' I've heard stories. She's been preying on ships and settlements for near ten years. Never leaves any survivors.
No survivors' Then where do the stories come from, I wonder?
Last time I saw you, you were all alone on a godforsaken island, shrinking into the distance. His fortunes aren't improved much.
Worry about your own fortunes, gentlemen. The deepest circle of Hell is reserved for betrayers and mutineers. So there is a curse. That's interesting.
You know nothing of Hell.
That's very interesting.

Mr. Turner , you are not a military man, you are not a sailor. You are a blacksmith and this is not the moment for rash actions. Do not make the mistake of thinking you are the only man here who cares for Elizabeth .
Please....
You. Sparrow!
Aye.
You are familiar with that ship ' the Black Pearl?
I've heard of it.
Where does it make berth?

Where does it make berth' Have you not heard the stories' Captain Barbossa and his crew of miscreants sail from the dreaded Isla de Muerta . It's an island that cannot be found except by those who already know where it is.
The ship's real enough. Therefore its anchorage must be a real place. Where is it?
Why ask me?
Because you're a pirate.
And you want to turn pirate yourself, is that it?
Never! They took Miss Swann .
Oh, so it is that you've found a girl. I see. Well, if you're intending to brave all, hasten to her rescue and so win fair lady's heart you'll have to do it alone, mate. I see no profit in it for me.
I can get you out of here.
How's that' The key's run off.
I helped build these cells. These are half pin-barrel hinges. With the right leverage and the proper application of strength' the door will lift free.
What's your name?
Will Turner .
That will be short for William , I imagine. Good, strong name. No doubt, named for your father, eh?
Yes.
Uh-huh. Well, Mr. Turner , I've changed me mind. If you spring me from this cell I swear on pain of death I shall take you to the Black Pearl and your bonny lass. Do we have an accord?
Agreed.
Agreed. Get me out.
Hurry. Someone will have heard that.
Not without my effects.
We're going to steal the ship. That ship'
Commandeer. We're going to commandeer that ship. Nautical term. One question about your business, boy, or there's no use going. This girl ' how far are you willing to go to save her?
I'd die for her.
Oh, good. No worries, then.
This is either madness or brilliance.
It's remarkable how often those two traits coincide. Everyone stay calm! we are taking over the ship.
This ship cannot be crewed by two men. You'll never make it out of the bay.
Son'I'm Captain Jack Sparrow. Savvy?
Quickly men!
Thank you, Commodore, for getting us ready to make way. We'd have had a hard time of it by ourselves.
When I was a lad living in England , my mother raised me by herself. After she died, I came out here, looking for my father.
Is that so?

My father, Will Turner . At the jail, it was only after you learned my name that you agreed to help. Since that's what I wanted, I didn't press the matter. I'm not a simpleton, Jack. You knew my father.
I knew 'im. Probably one the few who knew him as William Turner . Everyone else just called him Bootstrap or Bootstrap Bill.
Bootstrap?
Good man. Good pirate. I swear you look just like him.
It's not true. He was a merchant sailor. A good, respectable man who obeyed the law.
He was a bloody pirate, a scallywag.
My father was not a pirate.
Put it away, son. It's not worth you getting beat again.
You didn't beat me. you ignored the rules of engagement. In a fair fight, I'd killed you.

Then that's not much incentive for me to fight fair, then, is it' Now, as long as you're just hanging there, pay attention. The only rules that really matter are these ' what a man can do and what a man can't do. For instance, you can accept that your father was a pirate and a good man or you can't. But pirate is in your blood, boy, so you'll have to square with that someday. Now, me, for example, I can let you drown but I can't bring this ship into Tortuga all by me onesy, savvy' So' can you sail under the command of a pirate' Or can you not?
Tortuga ?
Tortuga . More importantly, it is indeed a sad life that has never breathed deep this sweet, proliferous bouquet that is Tortuga , savvy' What do you think?
It'll linger.
I'll tell you mate, if every town in the world were like this one, no man would ever feel unwanted.
Who was she'!
What' I may have deserved that.
Curse you for breathing, you slack-jawed idiot! Mother's love! Jack ! You should know better than to wake a man when he's sleeping. 'S bad luck.

Ah, fortunately I know how to counter it. The man who did the waking buys, the man who was sleeping, a drink. The man who was sleeping drinks it while listening to a proposition from the man who did the waking.
That was for the smell.
Keep a sharp eye.
Now, what's the nature of this venture of yourn?
I'm going after the Black Pearl. I know where it's going to be, and I'm going to take it.
Jack , it's a fool's errand. Why, you know better than me the tales of the Black Pearl.
That's why I know what Barbossa is up to. All I need is a crew.
From what I hear tell of Captain Barbossa , he's not a man to suffer fools, nor strike a bargain with one.
Well, then I'd say it's a very good thing I'm not a fool then, eh?
Prove me wrong. What makes ye think Barbossa will give up his ship to you?
Let's just say it's a matter of leverage, eh'
The kid?
That is the child of Bootstrap Bill Turner. His only child, savvy?
Is he, now'' Leverage,' says you. 'I think I feel a change in the wind,' says I. I'll find us a crew. There's bound to be some sailors on this rock crazy as you.
One can only hope. Take what you can'
So this is your able-bodied crew?
You, sailor!
Cotton, sir.
Mr. Cotton ' do you have the courage and fortitude to follow orders and stay true in the face of danger and almost certain death' Mr. Cotton ! Answer, man!
He's a mute, sir. Poor devil had his tongue cut out, so he trained the parrot to talk for him. No one's yet figured how.
Mr. Cotton 's... parrot. Same question.
Mostly, we figure, that means 'yes.'?
O'course it does. Satisfied?
And what's the benefit for us?
Anamaria.
I suppose you didn't deserve that one either.
No, that one I deserved.
You stole my boat!
Actually - borrowed. Borrowed without permission. But with every intention of bringing it back to you.
But you didn't!
You'll get another one.
A better one.
A better one!
That one.
What one' That one'! Aye, that one. What say you?
No, no, no, no, no, it's frightful bad luck to bring a woman aboard, sir.
It'd be far worse not to have her.
Aye, the compass doesn't point north but we're not trying to find north, are we' We should drop canvas, sir.
She can hold a bit longer.
What's in your head that's put you in such a fine mood, Captain?
We're catching up.
What did he use for rope?
Human hair'from my back. Let go of the anchor!
Let go of the anchor, sir!
Young Mr. Turner and I are to go ashore.
Captain! What if the worst should happen?
Keep to the code.
What Code is Gibbs to keep to if the worst should happen?
Pirate's Code. Any man that falls behind'is left behind.
No heroes amongst thieves, eh?

You know, for having such a bleak outlook on pirates you're well on your way to becoming one. Sprung a man from jail, commandeered a ship of the Fleet, sailed with a buccaneer crew out of Tortuga 'and you're completely obsessed with treasure.
That's not true. I am not obsessed with treasure.
Not all treasure is silver and gold, mate.
Jack !
Not yet. We wait for the opportune moment.
When's that' When it's of greatest profit to you?
May I ask you something' Have I ever given you reason not to trust me' Do us a favor ' I know it's difficult for you, but please stay here and try not to do anything stupid.
You're supposed to be dead!
Am I not' Oh. Palulay'palu-li-la-la-lulu, parlili' parsnip, pasley, par - partner, partner?
Parley?
Parley! That's the one. Parley! Parley!
Parley' Down to the depths whatever man that thought up 'parley!?
That would be the French.
How the blazes did you get off that island?
When you marooned me on that godforsaken spit of land, you forgot one very important thing, mate. I'm Captain Jack Sparrow .
Ah, well, I won't be making that mistake again. Gents, you all remember Captain Jack Sparrow ' Kill him.
The girl's blood didn't work, did it?
Hold your fire! You know whose blood we need?
I know whose blood ye need.
So you expect to leave me standing on some beach with nothing but a name and your word it's the one I need and watch you sail away in my ship?
No. I expect to leave you standing on some beach with absolutely no name at all, watching me sail away on my ship and then I'll shout the name back to you. Savvy?
But that still leaves us with the problem of me standing on some beach with naught but a name and your word it's the one I need.

Of the two of us, I am the only one who hasn't committed mutiny, therefore'my word is the one we'll be trusting. Although'I suppose I should be thanking you because, in fact, if you hadn't betrayed me and left me to die, I would have an equal share in that curse, same as you. Funny ol' world, innit'
Bo'sun : Captain, we're coming up on the Interceptor.
I'm having a thought here, Barbossa. What say we run up a flag of truce' I scurry over to the Interceptor, and I negotiate the return of your medallion, eh' What say you to that?
Anything that we can afford to lose'see that it's lost.
Apparently there's a leak.
Fire all!
Stop blowing holes in my ship!
Hey! Hey! Below!
Thanks very much.
Jack !
Bloody empty. That's not very nice. Where's the medallion?
Wretch!
Ahh. Where's dear William ?
Elizabeth !
Monkey!
Why, thank you, Jack .
You're welcome.
You've only got one shot, and we can't die.
Don't do anything stupid.
You can't. I can.
Like that.
Who are you?
No one. He's no one. A distant cousin of my aunt's nephew twice removed. Lovely singing voice, though ' eunuch.
So I'll be having that dress back before you go.
I always liked you.
Bo'sun : Too long!
I'd really rather hoped we were past all this.
Jack'. Jack . Did ya not notice' That be the same little island that we made you Governor of on our last little trip.
I did notice.
Perhaps you'll be able to conjure up another miraculous escape'but I doubt it. Off you go.
Last time, you left me a pistol with one shot.
By the powers, you're right. Were be Jack 's pistol' Bring it forward.
Seeing as there's two of us, a gentleman'would give us a pair of pistols.
Scene 19: (Marooned again)
That's the second time I've had to watch that man sail away with my ship.
But you were marooned on this island before, weren't you' So we can escape in the same way you did then.

To what point and purpose, young missy' The Black Pearl is gone and unless you have a rudder and a lot of sails hidden in that bodice ' unlikely - young Mr. Turner will be dead long before you can reach him.

But you're Captain Jack Sparrow . You vanished from under the eyes of seven agents of the East India Company. You sacked Nassau Port without even firing a shot. Are you the pirate I've read about or not' How did you escape last time?

Last time'I was here a grand total of three days, all right' Last time 'the rumrunners used this island as a cache. Came by, and I was able to barter a passage off. From the looks of things, they've long been out of business. Probably'have your bloody friend Norrington to thank for that.
So that's it then' That's the secret grand adventure of the infamous Jack Sparrow ' You spent three days lying on a beach, drinking rum'!
Welcome to the Caribbean , love.
Elizabeth and Jack : We're devils and black sheep and really bad eggs. Drink up me 'earties yo ho! Yo ho, yo ho a pirate's life for me.
I love this song! Really bad eggs! Ooh. When I get the Pearl back, I'm gonna teach it to the whole crew, and we'll sing it all the time!
And you'll be positively the most fearsome pirate in the Spanish Main .

Not just the Spanish Main , love. The entire ocean. The entire wo'ld. Wherever we want to go, we'll go. That's what a ship is, you know. It's not just a keel and a hull and a deck and sails that's what a ship needs but what a ship is'what the Black Pearl really is'is freedom.
Jack 'it must be really terrible for you to be trapped on this island.
Oh, yes. But the company is infinitely better than last time, I think. The scenery has definitely improved.
Mr. Sparrow 'I'm not entirely sure that I've had enough rum to allow that kind of talk.
I know exactly what you mean, love.
To freedom.
To the Black Pearl . No! Not good! Stop! Not good! What are you doing' You burned all the food, the shade! The rum!
Yes, the rum is gone.
Why is the rum gone?

One, because it is a vile drink that turns even the most respectable men into complete scoundrels. Two, that signal is over a thousand feet high. The entire Royal Navy is out looking for me, do you really think that there is even the slightest chance that they won't see it?
But why is the rum gone?
Just wait, Captain Sparrow. You give it one hour, maybe two, keep a weather eye out and then you will see white sails on that horizon.
'Must've been terrible for you to be trapped here, Jack . Must've been terrible for you.' Well it bloody is now! There'll be no living with her after this.
To rescue me. To prevent anything from happening to me.

If I may be so bold as to inject my professional opinion. The Pearl was listing near to scuppers after the battle. It's very unlikely she'll be able to make good time. Think about it. The Black Pearl . The last real pirate threat in the Caribbean , mate. How can you pass that up?
I am.
A wedding! I love weddings'drinks all around! I know. 'Clap him in irons,' right?

Mr. Sparrow , you will accompany these fine men to the helm and provide us with the bearing to Isla de Muerta . You will then spend the rest of the voyage contemplating all possible meanings of the phrase 'silent as the grave.' Do I make myself clear?
Inescapably clear.
I don't care for the situation. Any attempt to storm the caves could turn to an ambush.

Not if you're the one doing the ambushing. I go in, I convince Barbossa to send his men out with their little boats. You and your mates return to the Dauntless and blast the bejesus outta them with your little cannons, eh' What do you have to lose?
Nothing I'd lament being rid of.
Now, to be quite honest with you, there's still a slight risk for those aboard the Dauntless which includes the future Mrs. Commodore .
Guess there is reason to fret.
Beg your pardon.
Begun by blood?
Excuse me.
S'not possible.
Not probable.
Where's Elizabeth ?

She's safe, just like I promised. She's all set to marry Norrington, just like she promised. And you get to die for her, just like you promised. So we're all men of our word really except for Elizabeth who is, in fact, a woman.
Shut up! You're next.
You don't want to be doing that, mate.
No, I really think I do.
Your funeral.
Why don't I want to be doing it?
Well, because 'because the HMS Dauntless, pride of the Royal Navy, is floating just offshore. Waiting for you.
You think he wasn't telling the truth?

Just hear me out, mate. You order your men to row out to the Dauntless. They do what they do best. Robert 's your Uncle, Fannie 's your Aunt, there you are with two ships. The makings of your very own fleet. 'Course you'll take the grandest as your flagship, and who's to argue' But what of the Pearl ' Name me Captain, I'll sail under your colors, I'll give you ten percent of me plunder and you get to introduce yourself as'Commodore Barbossa. Savvy?
I s'pose in exchange, you want me not to kill the whelp.
No, no, not at all by all means, kill the whelp. Just not yet. Wait to lift the curse until the opportune moment. For instance' after you've killed Norrington's men' every' last' one.
You've been planning this from the beginning. Ever since you learned my name.
Yeah.
I want fifty percent of your plunder.
Fifteen.
Forty.
Twenty-five. And I'll buy you the hat. A really big one'Commodore.
We have an accord.
All hand's to the boats! Apologies. You give the orders.
Gents'take a walk.
Not to the boats'
I must admit, Jack , I thought I had ye figured. But it turns out that you're a hard man to predict.

Me' I'm dishonest. And a dishonest man you can always trust to be dishonest. Honestly. It's the honest ones you want to watch out for, because you can never predict when they're going to do something incredibly' stupid.
You can't beat me, Jack .
That's interesting. I couldn't resist, mate. Sorry.
So what now, Jack Sparrow ' Will it be it two immortals locked in an epic battle until Judgment Day and trumpets sound' Hmm?
Or you could surrender.
Your fianc� will be wanting to know you're safe.
If you were waiting for the opportune moment'that was it. Now, if you'll be so kind, I'd be much obliged if you'd drop me off my ship.
I'm sorry, Jack.
They done what's right by them. Can't expect more than that.
Jack Sparrow , be it known that you have?
Captain, Captain Jack Sparrow .
'impersonating an officer of the Spanish Royal Navy, impersonating a cleric of the Church of England?
Ah, yes.
It is.

Well! I'm actually feeling rather good about this. I think we've all arrived at a very special place, eh' Spiritually'Ecumenically'Grammatically' I want you to know that I was rooting for you, mate. Know that. Elizabeth 'it would never have worked between us, darling. I'm sorry. Will 'nice hat. Friends! This is the day that you will always remember as the day that '
No. He's a pirate.
I thought you were supposed to keep to the Code.
We figured they were more actual'guidelines.
Thank you.
Captain Sparrow 'the Black Pearl is yours.
On deck, you scabrous dogs! Man the braces! Let down and haul to run free. Now...bring me that horizon. And really bad eggs'drink up, me 'earties, yo ho.
Not *quite* according to plan.
Sorry, mate. Mind if we make a little side trip? I didn't think so.
You got what you went in for, then?
Complications arose, ensued, were overcome.
Captain, I think the crew, meaning me as well, were expecting something a bit more... *shiny*. What with the Isla de Muerta going all pear shaped, reclaimed by the sea, and the treasure with it.
Mm-hmm!
Aye, shiny.
Shiny?
Awk! Walk the plank!
Is that how you're all feeling, then? Perhaps dear old Jack is not serving your best interests as captain?
Do not blame the bird. Show us what is on that piece of cloth there.
What did the bird say?
Know that don't do no good.
Ohhh!
It's a key!
It does me.
Keys... unlock... *things*?
No! Much more better. It is a *drawing* of a key. Gentlemen, what do keys do?
So - We're going after this key!

No! If we don't have the key, we can't open whatever it is we don't have that it unlocks. So what purpose would be served in finding whatever need be unlocked, which we don't have, without first having found the key what unlocks it?
So... Do we have a heading?
You're not making any sense at all. Any more questions?
Cap'n?
Hah! A heading. Set sail in a... mmm... a general... in *that* way - direction.
Have you noticed lately... The captain seems to be actin' a bit strange... -er.
Come on, snap to and make sail, you know how this works. Come on, ?oy/?quick, ?oy/?quick, hey!
Lift the skin up!

Why is the rum always gone? Oh! *That's* why. As you were, gents. Ah! Bootstrap. Bill Turner. Is this a dream? I thought not. If it were, there'd be rum. I had some help retrieving the Pearl, by the way. Your son. And to what do I owe the pleasure of your carbuncle? Who? Ah. So it's you, then.  He shanghaied you into service, eh? It's funny what a man will do to forestall his final judgment - Technic - Yes, but the Flying Dutchman already *has* a captain, so there's re - Any idea when Jones might release said terrible beastie? On deck all hands! Make fast the bunt gasket! On deck! Scurry! ?Scurry-on/?Marty, I want movement! *I want movement!*
Do we have a heading?
All on deck! Run! And keep running! Run as if the devil himself and itself is upon us!
Which port?
Ah! Ooh! Run! Land. Oh! Euh!
Jack's hat! Bring 'er about!
Didn't say port. I said land. Any land. Agh!
Back to your stations! The lot o' ya!
No no! Leave it! Run!
For the love of mother and child, Jack, what's coming after us?
Shhh!
Heh-heh-heh.?tupayHey! ?Fo ?pes ?sa ?kapazun kapitan ?de ?la ?mezande, huh?
Nothing.
Eeseepi.
?: Wa-say kohn.

Kay-lay lam. Lam piki-piki. Lam eensy weensy. Lam say-say... eunuchy. Snip-snip.
Ball licky-licky!
Say-say lam shoop-shoop sha smalay-lama shoo-koo. Savvy? Ball licky-licky.
Jack, what did you tell them? No! What about Elizabeth? *Jack...!*
Save me!
cages
Thank you.
Jack
?No/?Oup! No no! ?Oy!/?Wait! No no! More wood! Big fire! *Big* fire! I am chief! Want big fire! Come on! ?Oy!/?Boy! Maboogie snickel-snickel. Tout de suite! Come on! More wood!

Time to go.
Hey!
Let's put some distance between us and this island, and head out to open sea.
Good doggie! ?Doggie. *Alas*, my children! This is the day you shall always remember as the day that you almost - ...Captain Jack... Sparrow.
Uh, that seems a bit contradictory, Captain.
Yes to the first, yes to the second, but only insofar as we keep to the shallows as much as possible.
Jack.
I have every faith in your reconciliatory navigational skills, Master Gibbs, now where is that monkey? I want to shoot *something*.
Elizabeth is in danger.
Ah.
She *is* locked up, in a prison, bound to hang for helping *you*!
Have you considered keeping a more watchful eye on 'er? Maybe just lock her up somewhere.
I need that Compass of yours, Jack. I must trade it for her freedom.
There comes a time when one must take responsibility for one's mistakes.
Cap'n.
Mister Gibbs!
By need, d'you mean a... trifling need, ?uh/?a... fleeting, as in say in a passing fancy?
We have a need to travel upriver.
What we need to do is make sail for Port Royal with all haste.
No, a... resolute and unyielding need.
You want me to find this?
William... I shall trade you the Compass, if you will help me... to find *this*.
This... is going to save Elizabeth?

No. *You* want you to find this. Because the finding this finds you incapacitorially finding and/or locating and your discovering the detecting of a way to save your ?dolly/?dotty belle ol'... what's-her-face. Savvy?
Not much.
How much do you know about Davy Jones?
What's all this? If you both fancy the dress, you'll just have to share, and wear it one after the other.
Yeah, it's gonna save Elizabeth.
I'll watch your back.
No worries, mates. Tia Dalma and I go way back. Thick as thieves. Nigh inseparable we are. Were. Have been. Before.
Mind the boat.
It's me front I'm worried about. Mind the boat.
I always know de wind was goin' blow you back to me one day.
Tia Dalma!
Not so well as I had hoped. Come.
There'll be no knowing here. We've come for help and we're not leaving without it. I thought *I* knew you.
What... service... may I do you? Hmmm? You know I demand payment.
Come.
No! You've no idea how long it took us to catch that.
I brought payment. Look! An undead monkey! Top that!
The Compass you bartered from me. It cannot lead you to dis?
We're looking for this.  And what it goes to.
Ayeee... Jack Sparrow does not know what he wants! Or... do know, but are loathe to claim it as your own. Your key go to a chest, and it is what lay inside the chest you seek, don't it?
Maybe. Why?
A wo-*man*. He fell in love.
A *woman*.
Let me see your hand.
I did not. I didn't know where the key was. But now we do. So all that's left is to climb aboard the Flying Dutchman, grab the key, you go back to Port Royal and save your bonnie lass, hey!
I am justMy little ###, where are you? ###
My eyesight's as good as ever, just so you know.
Yes?
Dirt. This is a jar of dirt.
If you don' want it, give it back.
Is the... jar of dirt going to help?
Den it helps.
No.
Must've run afoul of the reef.
Neither do you. Do *not* underestimate her.
I row over, search the ship until I find your bloody key.
So what's your plan, then?
I cut down anyone in my path.
And if there are crewmen?
Your chariot awaits you, sire! Ha, ha-ha-ha, ha-ha!
I like it. Simple, easy to remember.
Bon voyage! Ha-ha-ha!
Hey! If you *do* happen to get captured, just say Jack Sparrow sent you to settle his debt! Might save your life!
before attack
Douse the lamps.
You have a debt to pay. You've been captain of the Black Pearl for thirteen years. *That* was our agreement.
Oh.
Then you were a poor captain, but a *captain* nonetheless! Have you not introduced yourself all these years as *Captain* Jack Sparrow?
Technically, I was only captain for two years, then I was viciously mutinied upon.
One soul is not equal to another.
You have my payment. One soul to serve on your ship is already over there.
Price? Pttt!
Aha! So we've established my proposal is sound in principle, now we're just haggling over price.
One hundred souls, three days-uh.
Just how many souls do you think my soul is worth?
I keep the boy. A good-faith payment. That leaves you only ninety-nine more to go. Ha ha! Ha ha! Ha ha!
You're a diamond, mate. Send me back the boy, I'll get started right off.
I keep the boy. Ninety-nine souls-uh. But I wonder, Sparrow, can you live with this? Can you condemn an innocent man - a friend-uh - to a lifetime of servitude, in your name while you roam free?

Have you not met Will Turner? He's noble, heroic, *terrific* soprano. Worth at least four... maybe three and a half. And did I happen to mention... he's in love. With a girl. Due to be married. Betrothed.  Dividing him from her and her from him... would only be half as cruel as actually allowing them be joined in holy matrimony. Aye?
Three days.  Three days.
Yep! I'm good with it. Should we seal it in blood? I mean... mm-mm - ink? Uh!
Aye.
Oh, Mr. Gibbs.
And how do you intend to harvest these ninety-nine souls in three days?
Uh, I feel sullied and unusual.
Ah... Tortuga!
Fortunately, he was mum as the condition in which these souls need be.
It's an outrage. Port tariffs, berthing fees, *wharf* handling, and heaven help us, pilotage. Are we all to work for the East India Trading Company, then?
Tortuga.
Next!
I know what I want.
Including those four? That gives us - four!
How we going?
Sorry. Old habits and all that.
You're hired.
Aye!
Time to go?
Come on, men! Who wants some? Form an orderly line, I'll have you all one by one. Come on, who's first?
Thanks, mate. Carry on.
I'm here to find the man I love.
Come to join me crew, lad? Welcome aboard.
Meaning William Turner, Captain Sparrow.
I'm deeply flattered, son, but my first and only love is the sea.
Jack. I know Will came to find you. Where is he?
Elizabeth.  Hide the rum. You know, these clothes do not flatter you at all. It should be a dress or nothing. I happen to have no dress in my cabin.
Davy Jones?

Darling, I am truly unhappy to have to tell you this but... through an unfortunate and *entirely* unforeseeable series of circumstances that have nothing whatsoever to do with me, poor William has been press-ganged into Davy Jones' crew.
You *hired* me. I can't help it if your standards are lax.
You look bloody awful. What are you doing here?
Jack. All I want is to find Will.
You *smell* funny.
'Course.
Are you certain? Is that what you really want most?
And you have a way of doing that?
Because I would think, you'd want to find a way to *save* Will the most.
Oh, dear.
Well, there is a chest...
What contains the still-beating heart o' Davy Jones.
A chest of unknown size and origin.
You don't actually believe him, do you?
And whoever possesses that chest possesses the leverage to command Jones to do whatever it is he or she wants, including... saving brave William from his grim fate.
"Unique" here having the meaning of broken.
With this. My Compass... is unique.
Where does it point?
True enough. This Compass does not point north.
Oh Jack! Are you telling the truth?
It points to the thing you want most in this world.
To save Will?
Every word, love. And what you want most in this world is to find the chest of Davy Jones, is it not?
Cap'n.
By finding the chest of Davy Jones. Mister Gibbs!
Finally! Cast off those lines, weigh anchor, and prow that canvas!
We have our heading.
Miss Swann.
Will was working for Beckett, and never said a word.
Agh.
Beckett wants the Compass. Only one reason for that.
Agh.
Yes, he did say something about a chest.
Of course. He wants the chest.
And bad. Bad for every mother's son what calls himself a pirate. I think there's a bit more speed to be coaxed from these sails. Brace the foreyard!
A truly discomforting notion, love.
Persuasion.
Might I inquire how as to how you came by these?
Decidedly not.
Friendly?
Jack, the Letters, give them back.

Will strikes a deal for these and upholds it with honor. Yet you're the one standing here with the prize. Full pardon, commission as a privateer on behalf of England and the East India Trading Company. As if I could be bought for such a low price.
You do know Will taught me how handle a sword.
No. Persuade me.
It's a curious thing. There was a time when I would've given anything for you to look like that while thinking about me.
As I said... Persuade me.
I just thought I'd be married by now. I'm so ready to be married.
My tremendous intuitive sense of the female creature informs me that you are troubled.
No, thank you.
You know...  Lizzy... I *am*... captain of a ship. And *being* captain of a ship, I could in fact perform a... marriage. Right here. Right on this deck. Right... *now*!
Oh. Except for a sense of honor, and decency and-and a moral center. And personal hygiene.
Why not? We *are* very much alike, you and I. I and you. Us.
You seem very certain.
Trifles. You *will* come over to my side, I know it.
Why doesn't your Compass work?

One word love: curiosity. You long for freedom. You long to do what you want to do because you want it. To act on selfish impulse. You want to see what it's like. One day, you won't be able to resist.
Because you and I *are* alike, and there will come a moment when you have a chance to show it. To do the right thing.
Uh my Compass works fine.
You'll have the chance to do something... something courageous. And when you do, you'll discover something: that you're a good man.
I *love* those moments. I like to wave at them as they pass by.
I have faith in you. Want to know why?
All evidence to the contrary.
Curiosity. You're going to want it. A chance to be admired. And gain the rewards that follow. You won't be able to resist. You're going to want to know... what it tastes like.
Do tell, dearie.
But - seeing as you're a good man I know you will *never* put me in a position that would compromise my honor.
I *do* want to know what it tastes like.
You're pullin' too fast.
I want my jar of dirt.
This doesn't work. And it *certainly* doesn't show you what you want most.
Guard the boat, mind the tide... Don't touch my dirt.
Beg your pardon?
Yes it *does*. You're sitting on it!
"Mind the tide."
Move.
With good reason!
I do that quite a lot. Yet people are always surprised.
Sea turtles, mate. A pair of them, strapped to my feet.
How did you get here?
But I do owe you thanks, Jack.
Not so easy, is it?
After you tricked me onto that ship to square your debt with Jones.
You do?
I was reunited with my father.
What?
Everything you said to me... every word, was a lie!
Oh! Well... you're welcome, then.
I'm gonna kill Jones.
Pretty much. Time and tide, love. Oy! What're you doing?
I keep the promises I make, Jack. I intend to free my father. I hope you're here to see it.
Can't let you do that, William. 'Cause if Jones is dead, who's to call his terrible beastie off the hunt, eh? Now. If you please: The key.
Lord Beckett desires the contents of that chest. I deliver it, and get my life back.
I knew you'd warm up to me eventually.
Oh, I prefer to see it as the promise of redemption.
Ah. The dark side of ambition.
Enough!

Let us examine that claim for a moment, former Commodore, shall we? Who was it, who at the very moment you had a notorious pirate safely behind bars, saw fit to *free* said pirate, and take your dearly beloved all to hisself, hey? So who's fault is it, *really*, that you've ended up a rum-pot deckhand what takes orders from pirates?
'Ello, Poppet.
Still rooting for you, mate! Wup! Oh. Woah!
beach
Oh, shut it.
Right!
Jar of dirt!
We're not getting out of this.
Leave him lie! Unless you plan on using him to hit something with.
Aye!
Uh, I say we respect his final wish.
My prayers be with him. Best not wallow in our grief. The bright side is: You're back. And made it off free and clear.
He fell behind.
Enough!

I'll handle this, mate. Hey! Fishface! Lose something? Hey? Oup! Got it! Come to negotiate, eh, have you, you slimy git? Look what I got.  I got a jar of dirt! I got a jar of dirt! And guess what's inside it?
*Hard to starboard!*
Hard to starboard.
No. It's not a reef! Get away from the rail!
Why fight when you can negotiate? All one needs... is the proper leverage. Where is it? Where is the thump-thump?
Jack! The Pearl!
Abandon ship. Into the longboat.
He's right, we have to head for land.
She's only a ship, mate.
You came back. I always knew you were a good man.
We're not free yet, love.
Where's Jack?
Pirate.
deck
Bugger, bugger, bugger, bugger, bugger, bugger...! Come on... Come on... Not so bad. Oh! Hello, beastie.
Aye, Captain! Slacken braces, men, make all! How does she lie? ON DECK, a sailor turns: JACK SPARROW again.
Boatswain! Haul the halyard, slacken braces! PAN UP TO -- surprise! -- JACK SPARROW, a second one, in the rigging. Jack waves and calls down:

Perfect. What would my torment be without unusual crabs here to mock me. Jack grabs a handful of sand and flings it. The crab flinches back. Jack collapses. The crab scuttles forward, looks at Jack. Scuttles sideways, looks at the ship. The crab moves away to the pile of stones. Jack sits with his head lowered to his knees, alone in the dunes of the vast desert.

No wind. Nearby are several SMOOTH ROUND STONES. Jack picks one up and FLINGS it, skipping it across the sand. Jack sits down. Looks over. Weirdly, the stone comes rolling back. The stone rocks back and forth, an egg hatching. Cracks appear. The stone transform into a crab. The Crab turns toward Jack. Clicks, like it's laughing.
I hate boats. *
Interesting. The Hai Peng crew stumble out of the surf, bedraggled and * exhausted. Pintel and Ragetti still carry the ship plank they clinged to for safety.
Aye, Jack. The world needs you back something fierce.
I leave you folk alone for just a minute, and look what happens.
She hasn't told you? Then you'll have lots to talk about while you're here. (to Tia Dalma) As for you --
Why should I sail with any of you? Four of you have tried to kill me in the past. (he gets to Elizabeth) One of you succeeded. Will is startled. Jack notices. (It's news to all of them of course.)
And you are?

That's fair. All right, you're in. (to Ragetti) I don't need you. (to Gibbs) Gibbs, you get another chance. Marty. * Cotton, all right. And Cotton's Parrot, I'm a little iffy, but all right, you're a team -- Jack comes to Tai Huang.
That makes you the highest bidder. * Jack, satisfied, gestures for them to get on board. *
I have a ship.
They be my charts!
My ship, that makes me Captain.
I'm Captain of the starboard side! Two degrees starboard. The Captain will now take the helm.
Two degrees starboard --
Father! IN THE BOAT, Weatherby Swann glances over. His lantern lights half his face, leaving the rest in shadow.
Elizabeth. We're not back yet. He looks her in the eye. Elizabeth stares at him -- and realization dawns. Her next cry is one of anguish:
The Dutchman must have a Captain.
Come again?
Making port.
I prefer rum. Rum's good.
And salty wenches.
Even longer, given the deficit of rum.
Come sunset, it won't matter.
Oooh I like that.
Over there! What's that? I don't know! What do you think?
Not sun-set. Sun-down. And rise ... up! He stands. Points.
Thar! Over thar! He runs to port. Elizabeth follows everyone else to the rail. The ship rocks back.

There, it moved! Suddenly. It's very fast. Everyone follows -- what is he up to? The ship tilts that way some; the eyeball rolls. Elizabeth can't help but notice the activity. Jack suddenly seems to see something on back the port side --
He's rocking the ship.

It's not here! He runs across again, everyone follows, and the ship tilts more. Barbossa approaches the map -- sees UP IS DOWN, the upside down ship, the sunset. Picks up the rolling eye. A glare at Ragetti -- and Barbossa hands back the eye, goes back to studying the chart.
ON THE HORIZON, the FLASH OF GREEN shoots up!

And now up, is down! The Black Pearl rocks completely over into the water. Waves fill the sails and cause the ship to continue to roll -- UNDERWATER, chains, cannons, small objects fall down toward the depths. Jack, Will, Elizabeth, Barbossa hold on. Gibbs loses his grip, floats past -- Marty grabs him. Pintel and Ragetti, tied to the mast, look at each other, hold their breaths, cheeks bulging. Underwater, the Charts float past -- Will grabs them --

The pirates are gathering to fight Beckett. And you're a pirate. She swings her second pistol toward Jack. Jack stops aiming at Will, aims at her. Will aims at Jack, draws a second pistol to cover Barbossa.
I is arguing the point. If there's pirates a-gathering, I'm a-pointing my ship the other a-way.
Jack fires his pistol -- 'click.' Barbossa and Will and Elizabeth fire -- more 'clicks.' Pintel and Ragetti arrive with their pistols as the others check their own.
Still working on it. But I'm not going back to the Locker, Barbossa. Count on that.
I'll not be leaving my ship in your command.
You lead the shore party. I'll stay with the ship.
Criminey! Jack and Barbossa walk toward it. Pintel and Ragetti hustle past them toward -- The KRAKEN. It lies dead on the shore. Pintel finds a driftwood stick, pokes it.

An unholy one. Jack opens his own telescope, until it is long as Barbossa's ... then opens it further, until it is much longer. It droops at the end. Barbossa looks at him. He smiles. Barbossa snaps his telescope closed. Pintel and Ragetti crawl out of the surf as the other boats land. Jack and Barbossa step onto the sand, spot something. The rest of the pirates see it, too.
Aye, but that's a gamble with long odds, ain't it? There's no guarantee of coming back. But passing on -- that's dead certain. Jack contemplates that one. Barbossa regards the beast.
Sometimes things come back. We're living proof, mate.
Poisoned. Fouled by the body. The body is turned over -- Steng, the betrayer in Singapore. The wooden fid has been driven through his eye.
That's sad commentary, in and of itself. Marty stoops to drink -- jumps back with a shout. A BODY lies dead in the water, face down. Barbossa samples a handful of water, spits it out.
Sao Feng. You showing up here, 'tis truly a remarkable coincidence.

(points) He's the Captain. The landing party climbs on deck. CHINESE PIRATES -- too many to fight -- have taken over the Pearl. They've stripped the crew of their weapons, shackled them together. Elizabeth is held by TWO GUARDS. One of them rubs a swelling eye, the other has a bloody lip. Jack and Barbossa spot Sao Feng at the same time. Jack recognizes him, and tries to be inconspicuous behind Barbossa.
Hardly. Will strides up -- he spots Elizabeth in chains --
So now we can call it square.
Why didn't you tell me you were planning this?
It's always the quiet ones. Elizabeth, unchained now, eyes Will warily.
He did not mutiny against me, did he?
But you've no acrimony toward mutineers?
(points) I'm standing over there with them. Sao Feng grabs his arm.

He needs the Pearl -- (to Elizabeth) -- and you felt guilty -- (to Barbossa) -- and you and your Brethren Court ... Didn't anyone come to save me just because they missed me? Gibbs, Marty and Cotton raise their hands -- Pintel and Ragetti see, and follow their lead.

Here is our chance to find out. He nods his head toward a spot over Jack's shoulder -- Rounding the island is the ENDEAVOUR. Jack is yanked roughly away by Sao Feng's men. Jack has been escorted into the room. Beckett signals his guards to leave without turning. He stands at the window, peering out at the Black Pearl. Jack's effects are on the table -- including the Compass. So is a decanter and two glasses of Sherry. Jack searches the room surreptitiously under the following:
I'm not certain I can survive any more visits from old friends.
And you incurred a heavy debt to raise her back up, didn't you? It's not here, Jack.
People aren't cargo, mate.
Will someone be in soon to draw you a bath? Beckett takes them from Jack, puts them back in their places.
And you spared me any possibility of ending up as anything other than what I am. And for that, I thank you. He picks up a couple of the model ships from the table, pretends to "sail" them.

Now, far be it for me to give advice to you, but if I were me and you were you and we each had the same lack of trust in the other, imagine you are me. You would propose that rather than you telling me where the Brethren Court is meeting, you lead me there instead, whereupon you could serve up to me the Pirate Lords, the Nine Pieces of Eight, and the whole of the Brethren Court on a silver platter. And you being me, I would likely accept such an offer.
I've been. Once you've taken in the view, there's not much else to it.
My men are crew enough.

With a frilly linen napkin and a spicy banana on the side. Sao Feng's men guard Barbossa, Will, Elizabeth and the rest of Barbossa's crew. They all wear shackles. Mercer and a crew of sailors fan out on the ship. The sailors begin preparations to sail. One tries to take the wheel from Huang. Sao Feng and Will intercept Mercer.
Beckett gives Jack a knowing smile.
What interest is she to you?
Damn. He flings the compass to Jack. Then realizes:
Me. (long beat) Dead. He gestures to the compass: try it. Beckett opens the compass. From his reaction, it points to Jack. Jack scuttles sideways. From Beckett's reaction, the needle follows him.

Done! -- scoops up his effects and heads for the door Jack appears on deck, Beckett trailing. BODIES are littered, the aftermath of fighting. Beckett looks out -- the Empress sails off, already distant. CANNON FIRE and GUNSHOTS from the Black Pearl -- 588 ON THE BLACK PEARL, the last of Beckett's men are cut down. Mercer 588 is driven back, somersaults off the stern -- -- SPLASHES into the water. 589 ON THE ENDEAVOUR - Jack stares at the Pearl. Searches for a way 589 across. He shoves a GUNNER away from a cannon, kicks away the brace, flips the cannon over, facing into the ship. Beckett turns, looks -- Jack wraps a rope around the cannon wheel, a burning fuse lighter in hand.

You may kill me, but you may never insult me. Who am I? (beat) I'm Captain Jack Sparrow, mate. Do we have an accord? He nods, indicating his still-extended hand. Beckett hesitates -- THE SHIP IS ROCKED BY CANNON FIRE. Beckett falls forward. Jack grabs his hand, shakes it --
Send this piss-yellow traitor to the brig. Will is dragged away -- 591 ON THE ENDEAVOUR, OFFICER GROVES steps up to Beckett. 591
Tell me you didn't miss me. Barbossa turns away in disgust. Jack hops down, comes face- to-face with Will.
But not so odd as this. You came up with this all on your lonesome?
That's odd, isn't it? He drops down to the forecastle, looks over Will's handiwork.
Ah. You've not seen fit to trust her with it.
And how does your dearly beloved feel about your plan? Will returns to his work without answering.
You can if you want, but you won't -- and that makes it a choice. Will considers his words, unable to disagree.
"Can't" is a matter of fact.
Then I'll take on the obligation and not quite be completely free ... but immortal has to count for something. Now, here. He hands Will his compass.
I don't have the face for tentacles.

I hate him. Amid calm seas, the Empress is towed by the Dutchman. Other ships in the group are dark outlines against the sky. Elizabeth's eyes open at the sound of her jail door opening. Norrington is there.
(leans out) Give my regards to Davy Jones! He smile broadly, waves, disappears.
Aye. 607 ON THE FORWARD DECK, Tia Dalma finds Barbossa. 607
You know, for all that pirates are clever clogs capable of the most underhanded and duplicitous thinking ... we are an unimaginative lot when it comes to naming things.
The Black Pearl sails straight at the cliff, as if it will run aground. But revealed amid the rocks is a huge SEA TUNNEL -- The Black Pearl sails through. Gibbs glances over the side.
Step out, Mr. Cotton. (he takes the wheel) There's some dangerous cross tides ahead that will prove a trick to navigate.
Look at them all!

If you knew how many died making it deep enough -- you'd believe. They sail toward a distant light. The ship passes outside -- FROM ABOVE, Shipwreck Island is hollow, with a round water cove. In the center is Shipwreck City, constructed of broken, derelict ships. Moored around the city -- PIRATE SHIPS, of all types, from all over the world. PULL BACK to find Pintel, Ragetti and Jack as they stare out.
I cannot be summoned like some mongrel pup.

And I owe all of them money. Squawking seagulls circle above the Endeavour,diving down to the barrels on deck. The Flying Dutchman is moored alongside. The door is opened by Groves, who steps out of the way (quickly) to let an angry Jones pass.
Before he died, he named me captain of the Empress, and passed his lordship onto me.

We're still short one Pirate Lord. I'm content to wait until Sao Feng joins us. Sao Feng is dead. Elizabeth stands in the doorway, with Huang behind her. She starts in; Huang touches her shoulder, gestures to the globe.
Will you never forgive me? (answering the question) He fell to the Flying Dutchman. An uproar of concern, OVERLAPPING dialogue --
Hers, I'll wager.
And it matters not how they found us! The question is, what will we do now that they have?
(shrugs) Not among us.
Sao Feng would have agreed with Barbossa.
Shoot him and then cut out his tongue! And then shoot his tongue. And trim that scraggly beard.
And, meanwhile, our enemy is bearing down upon us.
This is politics.
It's not impossible. Is it so improbable?
Or at least grant 'em to the one of us who summoned the rest of us and connived all of us to set her free. Barbossa shoots him a glare. The other pirates eye Barbossa suspiciously.

Or, we can release Calypso, and we can pray she'll be in a merciful mood. But can we pretend that she is anything other than a woman scorned, like which fury hell hath no? No, we cannot. Res ipso loquitur, tabula in naufragi, we are left with only one option. I agree with -- (gets it out) Captain Swann: we must fight.

Cuttlefish. Nasty little buggers. Pen 'em up together, and they'll devour each other without a second thought. So, yes, we could hole up here, well-provisioned and well-armed, and half of us will be dead within the month, and half of the other half dead the month after that. The pirate lords can't argue with that.
Aye! Here, here!

Slander and calumny! I have only ever embraced that oldest, noblest of all pirate traditions. My fellow mariners and shellbacks, I submit that here, now, that is what we all must do. We must fight to run away!
Yes! And should we kick it hard enough and long enough ...
Ah, but Jones does have a body, doesn't he? Such as it is.
Did I now? I call on Captain Teague, Keeper of the Code! Barbossa grins at Jack's "oh, crap, not him" expression. Sumbhajee makes another small gesture; Ashay interprets:
You made that up.
Teague retires to a chair at the back of the court, begins strumming a mandolin.
"It be the duties of the King to declare war, parley with shared adversaries, co-ordinate forces ..." Fancy that.
(raises hand) I vote for Ammand the Corsair.
I call for a vote! Barbossa is dismayed.
Barboosa knows he's been foxed. Elizabeth is shocked, but quick on the uptake.
Elizabeth Swann.
Very well. What say you, Captain Swann, King of the Brethren Court? Elizabeth gaze takes in all the Pirate Lords. She stands, makes her pronouncement.
Ah. Am I to understand, then, that we will not keep to code? SPLANG! One of Teague's mandolin strings breaks. Jack knows Teague's got his back on this. The lords exchange glances.

It's not just about living forever, Jackie. The trick is, living with yourself forever. He takes a shrunken head from his belt, offers it to Jack. Odd. Jack takes it. Teague nods to him, and leaves him to his thoughts. Shipwreck island in the background ... PAN TO REVEAL the Black Pearl as it joins the Empress, and the collected pirate ships, ready for battle. Pirates sharpen swords, clamber over the ship, make ready for sea. ON DECK, Marty peers ahead, into fog-shrouded waters -- 619 Out of the fog, a SINGLE SHIP appears, the ENDEAVOUR. 619
What? You've seen it all. And survived. That's the trick, isn't it? To survive.
(to Will) You be the cur that led these wolves to our door.

Parlay? A sparkling white strip of sand. Jack, Elizabeth and Barbossa walking away from a longboat beached on one side, toward a second longboat on the other side. The threesome draw near to three others: Beckett, Davy Jones and Will. They regard each other in silence.
Will, I've been aboard the Dutchman ... I understand the burden you bear. But I fear that cause is lost.
There! Listen to the tool.
There never was.
Even if that was my plan -- and I'm not admitting to anything -- there's not a tinker's chance of it coming off anymore. (to Elizabeth) Is there?
You escaped.
That debt was paid. (to Elizabeth) With some help.
Done.
Not done.
Blaggar! Jack evades, but not quite -- Jack's circlet coin drops to the sand. Jack the Monkey scurries to pick up the coin. Jack raises his eyes to Barbossa. The two men regard each other.
As you command, your nibs. He starts to cross to Beckett -- Barbossa grabs Jack's shoulder and whirls him around even as he draws his sword.
Advise your 'Brethren': you can fight, and all of you will die. Or you can not fight, in which case only most of you will die.
You have no idea.
Should he being doing that?

I did not -- All three suddenly clutch their heads and yell in pain. They look over at Wyvern Jack -- he's got his BRAIN in his HAND. He squeezes it again; again, all three clutch their heads and yell in pain.
The whelp.
Stop it! Stop! You're giving me a terrible headache -- And that reminds him of something:
Half-barrel hinges! Never work.
-- Think like the whelp Think like the whelp Think like the whelp --
I miss him already.
Wish us luck, boys. We might need it. He moves past the bars. The Jacks watch him go.
Someone has to stay and guard the chest.
Good one. I just came to see my effects. Admirable though it is, why are you here when you could be somewhere else?

And now, anon, adieu. Grabs a sail, loosens the bottom tie. The sail, partially free, fills with wind, and carries Jack to the upper rigging. Jack lands, impressed with himself. Inches along, looks up -- and suddenly Jones is there. He draws his sword.
(looking for an escape route) To my great regret. (a-ha! found one!) But it's never too late, he? Jack sheathes his sword, tips his hat --

Have you never loved, Jack? My freedom was forfeit long ago. Jones leaps at Jack, swords clashing -- The two ships are drawn closer in an ever-tightening circle. The giant masts of the two ships tilt toward -- close enough for attackers to swing on ropes, cross from ship to ship -- Cannon fire BLASTS the Pearl. SOLDIERS from the Flying Dutchman swarm across, attack Will and Elizabeth. Will takes advantage of a short break in the action (near capstan)
I can set you free, Jones.
No, you don't. Jones displays the key at the end of a tentacle on his beard.
I already have the key. For a moment, Jones almost believes him, but then smiles, display the key at the end of a tentacle.

Jones is hit; the chest, fall from his grip -- -- the chest SMASHING down on Haddrass as he tries to sit up; his entire head is forced down into his body. The chest tumbles free -- -- just as Will lands on the deck, arrived from the Pearl. He bends to pick up the chest, moves away -- Jones strides along the deck, moves through the fighting. A REDCOAT stoops to pick up Jones' sword, examine it. Jones takes it from him and runs him through, never slowing -- Will glances over his shoulder, then back ahead -- where Maacus is right in front of him, blocking the way. On Pintel and Ragetti, smirking, standing on either side of a cannon ... they're up to something. REVEAL Jack-the-Monkey crouched inside the barrel. Pintel lights the fuse -- -- KABOOM! -- the Monkey SHRIEKS in GLEE -- -- SMACK! Jack-the-Monkey slams into Maacus; he tears at it, tries to get it off his face -- Jack continues to swing around, looks down, sees -- Will moves past -- then is suddenly floored by -- Bootstrap Bill. The chest slides away. Will stands, has only a second to recognize his father --
Hullo, that's mine! Jack grabs the pistol from the Crewman as he head-butts him off the line. Jack comes swinging back around behind Jones, FIRES the pistol --
The masts be tangled! The Dutchman is going down, and us with it! Gibbs cranes his neck, stares at the masts, turning --

(he lets out a whimper at the sword) Jack looks, pulls a bayline pin out of the capstan, uses that to block Jones' attack -- Jack dodges, keeping the capstan between them. Jones goes straight through the capstan -- Jack spins the capstan, turning Jones around to come out the other side -- As Will battles Bootstrap, giving ground -- Pintel, Ragetti and Gibbs arrive on deck -- -- as Barbossa fights with the wheel, straining to keep the two ships apart. He yells down --
It's a heady tonic ... (tosses the heart in his hand) ... holding life and death in the palm of your hand.

Do you? Jack stands with the chest open, and Jones still-beating heart in his hand. He squeezes it -- and Jones staggers, clutches at his chest. Jack smiles. He's got it all under control. Finally. Jones regains his balance ... takes stock of the situation.
Is it? DAVY JONES STABS WILL TURNER. With Norrington's sword.
Self-serving and dishonest I'll give you, but cruel is a matter of perspective, is it not?
Pintel, Ragetti, Marty, Gibbs, Cotton, all want to protest, but Jack cuts each of them off --
Belay that belay that!
